text.english: Teorema: \(\texttt{ins}\) respects the \(\texttt{ordinatoPP}\) property, in other words, if a binary tree is ordered then it will remain ordered if we add a node using \(\texttt{ins}\), i.e. \[ \forall t \in BT_\mathbb{N} . \; \forall n \in \mathbb{N} . \; \texttt{ordinatoPP}(t) = \texttt{true} \implies \texttt{ordinatoPP}(\texttt{ins}(n,t)) = \texttt{true} \]
text.italiano: Teorema: \(\texttt{ins}\) rispetta la proprietà \(\texttt{ordinatoPP}\), ovvero, se un albero binario è ordinato, allora rimarrà ordinato se aggiungiamo un nodo utilizzando \(\texttt{ins}\), i.e. \[ \forall t \in BT_\mathbb{N} . \; \forall n \in \mathbb{N} . \; \texttt{ordinatoPP}(t) = \texttt{true} \implies \texttt{ordinatoPP}(\texttt{ins}(n,t)) = \texttt{true} \]

theorem.coq: Theorem ordinatoPP_ins: forall (t : bte nat) (n : nat) , #implies ordinatoPP t = true #to ordinatoPP (ins n t) = true.
